description.narrative: Multi-Partner Trust Fund - Funding from Germany. UN Partnership for Action on inclusive Green Economy, aiming to assist interested countries in developing, adopting and implementing inclusive green economy policies and strategies.

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

comment.narrative: At least 1 regional initiative supported. At least 1 national green finance initiatives supported.

PAGE is supporting innovative green finance work in Latin American countries including Peru, Ecuador, and Brazil, and in Asia including India, Indonesia, Kyrgyzstan, and Mongolia. These countries have been selected based on a set of criteria that takes into consideration in-country opportunities, government demand and ownership, and complementary PAGE/UNDP GE programming. Priority has been given to existing, graduated and pipeline PAGE countries, and opportunities to leverage links with complementary UN programmes including UNDP BIOFIN, UNDP’s Climate Promise, UNDP Green Commodities Programme, UNDP-UNEP Poverty Environment Action for SDGs, UN-REDD, the One Planet network, and programmes funded by the Global Environment Facility and Green Climate Fund.
This work is supporting national and sector policy frameworks that facilitate public-private investments in sectors such as forestry, agriculture and green commodity value chains, as well as other innovative green finance and budget mechanisms.
Latina America and Caribbean In Peru, a mechanism for Public Works for Tax Deductions has been created. Despite the progress made using this mechanism, its potential for funding green infrastructure with private sector funds has not yet been realized in spite of potential for strong social impact and interest from the private sector. By 2021 it is expected that over US$ 1.8 billion (equivalent to 1% of GDP) will be mobilized for infrastructure projects through the Public Works for Tax Deductions mechanism. If at least 3% of this is directed to investment in greener, biodiversity friendly projects, an estimated US$ 54 million can be catalysed.
To help realize this potential, UNDP is using PAGE funds through BIOFIN to: 1) collect and develop data and knowledge products that demonstrate the economic, environmental and social benefits of green, biodiversity-friendly finance projects; 2) create an enabling environment for investments in biodiversity projects; 3) develop pilot projects that guide the use of the mechanism so that private enterprises, subnational governments, universities and government sectors can engage. This work is owned by the Ministry of Environment in coordination with the Ministry of Economy and Finance, through private sector associations including PROINVERSION and ALOXI. An initial study has been finalized to prioritize the companies that would be interested in using the mechanism of investments through Work for Taxes (WxT) to finance projects related to biodiversity and green economy. Some 23 companies were prioritized and 50% of these companies wish to use the mechanism to finance natural infrastructure for nearly US$ 15 million. The study has served as an input for the systematization of public investment projects in biodiversity and ecosystem management that BIOFIN carried out, to define a potential portfolio of projects that contribute to closing investment gaps in biodiversity and ecosystem services, an essential input for the mobilization of resources. With BIOFIN support the government has now developed a portfolio of environmental projects to be financed by WxT. UNDP signed a MOU with ALOXI (gathering 30 private companies) to establish a framework of cooperation and on 16 September 2020 a webinar attended by 744 participants was organized to increase private sector awareness of this mechanism. This work is linked to the PAGE exit and sustainability Strategy being coordinated with the General Department of Economic and Environmental Finance of MINAM in including through the National Competitiveness and Productivity Plan (Chapter 4: Promoting local and external financing mechanisms, e.g. Green Protocol, and Chapter 9: Promote environmental sustainability in the operation of economic activities). Targeted Scenario Analysis to inform Greener, Inclusive Public/Private Investments In LAC, a series of sectoral green policy and investment decisions are being informed by a participatory economic valuations approach called Targeted Scenario Analysis (TSA). Achieving the SDGs, especially SDG 8 continues to be a challenge for Governments. Governments and their private sector partners have identified the need to strengthen the evidence-based information needed to inform and make the case for the design, financing, implementation, and monitoring of a more effective, efficient, and sustainable sector development policies and investment plans. In 2020 PAGE continued to support the implementation of demand-driven Targeted Scenario Analysis (TSA) applied to priority economic sectors in Colombia, Ecuador, and Peru.
UNDP’s TSA is an innovative economic valuation approach designed to provide sector-focused economic information to decision-makers from the public and/or private sector, who have the mandate to design and implement policies, development plans, and investment strategies at national and sub-national levels. The TSA analysis produces a balanced time-bound presentation of economic loses or gains, which weighs up the pros and cons of two different management scenarios. The first is a scenario that continues with the business as usual (BAU) of promoting high productivity with unsustainable ecosystem management. The second is an alternative scenario that follows a more sustainable development path in which ecosystems management is more efficient and cost-effective. This alternative path is defined as sustainable ecosystem management (SEM). TSA recommendation will be used to make informed decisions that will result in more sustainable policies and better-funded implementation plans.
Despite delays due to COVID-19, two of the three PAGE-financed TSA were completed, with significant progress on the third.
The TSA studies are linked to on-going national policy revision processes and related GEF Projects in each country. The TSAs are analyzing the current economic impacts of BAU practices, and the potential increase of net benefits of shifting to SEM.
Colombia’s TSA is analyzing deforestation and livestock production in the Amazon region. The TSA process has been launched but is delayed due to COVID-19.
In Ecuador, the TSA focuses on illegal artesian and small-scale mining and is linked to the on-going revision of mining policies. The TSA study was recently finalized in late 2020 and offers policy recommendations on how to ensure more sustainable small-scale mining. Officials of the Ministry of Mining and Ministry of Environment have revised the document and have endorsed the results. The study also incorporates comments from other stakeholders. The study will now be formally shared with the Vice Ministers of Mining and Environment. A complementary policy brief has been prepared and is under review.
In Peru, the study focuses on deforestation-free palm oil production. It is part of a broader TSA that includes sustainable cacao and coffee production in the Amazon. The TSA in Peru supports the formulation of national coffee, cocoa, and oil palm action plans. A draft TSA report on cacao and palm (two TSAs in one) wass completed in late 2020. The government, and cacao and palm producers, including JUNPALMA have welcomed the initial study results and policy recommendations. The report and policy brief is in its final stages of review.
PAGE supported TSAs are part of a broader UNDP effort to use economic valuation to advance the mainstreaming of sustainable development policies. Lessons learned from the direct support of PAGE describe above are being used to also to influence and inform additional TSAs financed by UNDP-managed GEF projects including some PAGE countries:
-Paraguay on livestock/beef: the final report will be available in January 2021 (in Spanish); - Thailand in Illegal Wildlife Trade: the final report expected for April 2021 (in English); and - Kazakhstan on Forestry: The final report is expected for March 2021 (in English).
Communications strategies and policy discussions are being planned to promote and disseminate the TSA results. All finalized TSAs summaries are available here: https://www.greencommodities.org/content/gcp/en/home/tools/TSA.html
Asia Special PAGE funds are being used to implement a range of innovative green finance initiatives and pilots in Asia including the following types of thematic and technical work.
In Mongolia, UNDP continued to support a pilot project at the Ministry of Health designed to assist the Ministry of Finance to integrate the SDGs into the budgeting process. In 2019, the pilot was extended to the Ministry of Environment and Tourism (MOET), with an initial focus on SDG 15 and linked GE priorities. The initiative is designed to ensure that public expenditures are more directly aligned with priorities identified in the country’s GE Action Plan and related environmental strategies. UNDP Mongolia worked with the MOF to introduce a gradual integration of SDGs into the budget cycle both horizontally (coverage of sectors) and vertically (processes to ensure state and local budget decision-making using SDGs). In 2019, an initial expenditure trend analysis was conducted, and the exercise to align budgeting with SDV/SDG priorities and indicators was launched covering three areas: specially protected areas; desertification and land degradation; and water resource management. As a result of the pilot, the Ministry of Finance has already reallocated annual budgets focusing on environmentally protected areas, desertification and land degradation, and water resource management. UNDP continued this work in 2020, including: on-site mission trips to selected provinces to monitor the implementation of the SDGs budget at local government levels, policy objectives mapping to update the approval of the long-term development policy vision document Vision-2050. The work also included completing a Fiscal Analysis of the Environment and Tourism Sector to support the implementation of the 2030 Agenda in Mongolia. The application of the SDG budgeting methodology and template was also expanded by the MET to develop seven budget programmes along with performance indicators for the 2021 fiscal year.
In Mongolia, UNDP continued to support preparations for a private equity fund designed to diversify the economy away from extractives and incentivize sustainable and more competitive cashmere value chains. This work complements other initiatives funded by the GCF, GEF, and the UNDP Green Commodities Programme. There are several challenges to establishing such a fund. UNDP is now looking to identify one or more potential Fund managers for a two country, Mongolia-China Fund. It will support companies that advance climate-resilient livestock management and help reverse pasture degradation, complementing efforts funded by the Green Climate Fund and Global Environment Facility. This work builds on the PAGE Sustainability Strategy and aligns with the national Green Growth Action Plan and SD Vision. Sustainable Fibers Fund (MCSFF) quality, an experienced international consultant was engaged to assist UNDP with a concept note that will help outline the feasibility of the fund. The consultant has completed background analysis of the MCSFF Concept Paper, including Risk Matrix Preparation, Fiber Value Chain analysis in China and Mongolia, and in 2021 will prepare an MCSFF proposal request and provide support to contract a fund manager.
In India, Access and Benefit sharing provides for the use of natural resources in an efficient and sustainable manner for various purposes, including commercial utilization. It is a tool which simultaneously enables the national mandates of biodiversity conservation and economic development in a sustainable way. Access and benefit-sharing (ABS) refers to the way in which genetic resources may be accessed, and how the benefits that result from their use are shared between the people or countries using the resources (users) and the people or countries that provide them (providers).
The finance potential of ABS benefit sharing in Uttarakhand is estimated at $15 million. When extrapolated across all of India’s 29 States and 7 Union Territories, there could be a quantum jump (annual ABS revenues of at least USD 200 million) in terms of resources available for conservation and contribute to a greener economy and sustainable livelihood. There is also high potential for ABS impact on job creation and other socio-economic benefits. The Biodiversity Act, 2002 provides that ABS money could, in addition to conservation and promotion of biological resources, be spent on socio-economic development in areas from which the resources have been harvested. If 50% of the annual potential ABS revenues is spent on wages, the potential for employment is about 50 million working days for agricultural workers per year.
With PAGE funding, UNDP is helping India to: 1) develop a robust methodology to define ABS beneficiaries and a system to disburse the funding to the providers of bio-resources, i.e. local communities; 2) demonstrate the methodology in a pilot state; 3) strengthen capacity building of users and providers of biological and genetic resources as well as the State Biodiversity Boards (of pilot states) in transferring ABS funds; and 4) prepare a concept note on how to scale up the system to other States and barriers identified in the pilot. To develop a robust methodology to define ABS beneficiaries and a system for disbursing the funding received through the ABS process, a Working Group ABS has been created (including UNDP) which will develop the methodology. A series of webinars have been planned to discuss and disseminate the knowledge developed in the working group. In 2020, the first meeting of the expert working group was held on 14 Oct 2020 and the next is planned in mid Jan 2021. The results from the Working Group are expected to be ready by April 2021. In addition, under the PAGE support the NBA and UNDP also commissioned an assignment in 2020, to develop and pilot an innovative voluntary certification scheme for incentivizing the compliance of ABS in India. The assignment is in progress and pilot demonstration is expected by April 2021. In Indonesia, UNDP is supporting innovative “blue” and “green” financing mechanisms. Through its Innovative Financing Lab (IFL), UNDP is assisting the Government to develop the world’s first framework for blue financial instrument, with work initiated in 2018. This exercise aims to open capital markets for investment in blue economy in line with SDG 14 (Conserve and Sustainably Use the Oceans, Seas and Marine Resources) and to increase the involvement of woman in the marine industry by highlighting gender equality. In 2019, the Blue Financing Framework was launched during the Archipelagic and Island State Forum in Manado, Indonesia.
Through PAGE and its IFL, UNDP continues to support the Green “Sukuk” Bond in collaboration with the Ministry of Finance. Since 2015, this work has included: 1) strengthening public financial management; (2) supporting national systems that allow for better decision making; and (3) developing impact measurement frameworks for green investments and SDG related outcomes. With additional PAGE support, in February 2018, the first Green “Sukuk” Bond was launched by the Ministry of Finance, with a second launched in February 2019 for the retail sector. This work is being complement by the UNEP-UNDP Poverty Environment Action Programme (PEA), which supports the development of training modules for impact monitoring and reporting for Green Bonds, as well as an impact measurement manual and feasibility study on the Blue Bond.
In 2020, the Blue Financing Framework was further discussed with key stakeholders, including different Ministries (Coordinating Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Investment, Ministry of Finance, and Bappenas) and the Development Bank of Singapore (DBS). DBS expressed interest in issuing the potential worlds first blue Sukuk, for example, by providing inputs to the development of the Blue Bonds/Blue Sukuk Framework or participation in external review processes and discussions with potential stakeholders. Sukuk are financial products whose terms and structures comply with sharia, to create returns similar to those of conventional fixed-income instruments like bonds.
Through its IFL, UNDP also supports the Green Sukuk Bond in collaboration with the Ministry of Finance. In 2020, with PAGE support, UNDP assisted MOF to publish a Second Green Sukuk Allocation and Impact Report in early March 2020, which provides insights into how the proceeds have been used. Also, Indonesias Retail Green Sukuk Study was published in July 2020, which provides a comprehensive analysis of the impact, outcome, challenges, and prospect of green Sukuk issuance in domestic market. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the government issued the Third Global Green Sukuk amounting USD 750 million in June 2020 and second Retail Green Sukuk in November 2020. The instruments finance three green sectors: sustainable transport, resilience to climate change, and energy efficiency.
In Kyrgyzstan, agricultural subsidies have failed to improve the welfare of farmers, and disincentive farmers to adopt green/organic practices. The subsidies directed to agricultural producers encompass many types that are effective including cash transfers, tax exemptions or reductions, reduced fees and tariffs and pension bonuses. There is a need to efficiently remove or green these subsidies in an orderly manner and with the smallest social cost to the most vulnerable groups. An analysis is needed of the incentive structure and impact of potential reforms, as well as a compensation package for the transition towards greener agricultural practices. Some subsidies and privileges, such as the interest rate subsidies to agricultural producers, could be greened and encourage green practices that benefit small farmers.
PAGE supports fiscal policy reform in the agricultural sector in the Kyrgyz Republic to remove harmful subsidies and shift towards sustainable practices, through two closely coordinated initiatives by UNEP and the UNDP-Biodiversity Finance Initiative (BIOFIN).
Through BIOFIN with PAGE resources, UNDP has started to: 1) identify one priority subsidy to reduce, green or phase out; 2) conduct political economy and environmental and social Impact analysis for the selected subsidy; 3) design multiple scenarios (business as usual, reduction and full phase out) to reduce, green or phase out the prioritized subsidy, outlining potential financial, socio-economic, gender and environmental impacts and suggestions; 4) develop an action agenda to reform the selected subsidy, including the drafting of all required legislation, regulations, potential compensation mechanisms, potential categories for exemption (e.g. vulnerable groups), phase down/out timelines, advocacy plan, capacity development and the required budget for the reform process; and 5) support the reform process with the drafting of regulatory documents, national debates, communication & advocacy, capacity development and any other type of assistance required as the process evolves.
The process is based on intensive consultation with stakeholders, including the Ministries of Agriculture, Finance and representation of groups likely to be affected by the subsidy reform. This initiative is implemented in close coordination with the on-going work of UNEP under the PAGE Project on ‘Fiscal policy reforms for sustainable, climate-resilient agriculture’. A coordination meeting between UNEP, IEED and BIOFIN took place in September 2020. A joint work plan is under development. The activity will also be closely coordinated with the Inter-agency Working Group on Reforming Harmful Subsidies under the Public Council on Transition to Green Economy of the Parliament of the Kyrgyz Republic. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, there were significant delays in the recruitment processes, however the national company recently started and the international consultant that will support them was hired in July 2020. Aligned with this, UNEP is conducting a technical study which will provide an analysis of the environmental impacts of current agriculture subsidies and potential subsidy reform scenarios. To be finalized in June 2021, the study is being implemented by the International Institute for Environment and Development (IIED). It is proposed that a joint (PAGE-BIOFIN) technical report on agriculture subsidies will be prepared for the Government to bring together the analysis in a final, consolidated product in 2021.
At least 1 regional initiative supported. At least 1 national green finance initiatives supported.

Uncovering the progress made and opportunities lying ahead, the report “Latin America Green Finance State of the Market 2019” provides a detailed insight into finance for climate change solutions in the region. It looks at green bond issuance from public entities, as well as issuance from companies operating in climate-aligned sectors, providing examples of instrumental policies and initiatives in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Mexico, Peru and Central America.
In May, more than 300 global leaders gathered in Peru for the Good Growth Conference, a unique learning and networking event centred around sustainable commodity supply chains in the forests and agricultural sector. The conference highlighted how the demand for sustainable commodities, their production and financing can accelerate progress towards SDGs. At this occasion, PAGE supported a two-day workshop encouraging a select group of journalists to explore solution journalism in the context of climate change and deforestation. Jointly hosted by UNDP’s Green Commodities Programme and the Thompson Reuter Foundation, the journalists were first exposed to key sustainability solutions in major agricultural commodities, then attended the opening sessions of the Conference, with opportunities to interview Ministers, and afterwards journeyed to the Amazon to put solution journalism into practice.
In July, seven key players in partnership who are driving the green economy agenda – GGGI, OECD, GIZ, GEC, PEA, GGKP and PAGE – hosted the side event “Fast, Fair, and Green” at the High-Level Political Forum in New York. The event brought together a diverse cross-section of attendees focused on creating green and inclusive economies. With presentations from UN Heads of agencies, CEOs, and Ministers, it served as a platform to inspire leaders at the highest levels of governance, civil society and businesses on key steps in a green economy transition. With the event, the green economy partners launched the “Principles, Priorities, and Pathways” to guide future work as well as the new GGKP Green Industry Platform and Green Finance Platform.
The Green Latin America Awards aim to energise the green economy in the region by recognizing projects and sustainable actions implemented in 10 categories inspired by the accomplishments of the SDGs. At its sixth edition, in August in Ecuador, PAGE organized a panel on “The role of the financial system to boost the development of the green economy”, which analysed the current conditions of the financial system and the role of alternative financing mechanisms to promote the green economy and achieve the SDGs. The discussions highlighted the challenges Latin American financial institutions are facing to reach the micro-entrepreneurial and entrepreneurial sectors that are becoming increasingly essential for the emerging green economy in the region.

At least 1 regional initiative supported. At least 1 national green finance initiatives supported.Latin America and Caribbean
In Latin America UNDP continued its support the “From Commitment to Action” Initiative. Many commitments have been made by governments and companies, to reduce deforestation resulting from the production of cash crops, but progress in achieving the goals set out in these commitments has been slow and uneven. Starting in the Amazon, where production of commodities including soy, beef, palm, coffee, and cocoa continues to contribute to forest loss and degradation, UNDP is helping countries to move “From Commitment to Action”. A synthesis report outlining the results of this work was prepared and launched. The Report is available here: https://www.greencommodities.org/content/gcp/en/home/global-initiatives/c2b.html
Other communications and advocacy materials include: • The blog ‘5 Routes to Go From Commitment to Action’: https://www.greencommodities.org/content/gcp/en/home/media-centre/5-routes-to-go-from-commitment-to-action.html • The blog includes a short promo video for social media: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E9rgLXbFFtE&feature=emb_title • A Social Media Kit has been created with inks to the blog and promo video: https://trello.com/b/wtFxpd5t/social-media-kit-fc2a-report
For the third straight year, Latin America Green Awards and PAGE worked as strategic partners to promote local actions towards sustainable development in the region. In 2020, the alliance had two main components, a High-Level Dialogue on Green Economy and Sustainable Development and a PLV-PAGE Connects Market Place. From the conclusions and lessons learned from the 2018 and 2019 editions, improvements were made in 2020 to increase the regional reach and discover more ventures in Latin America and the Caribbean. Due to COVID19, the Awards were conducted online. Over 200 LAC enterprises participated, an increase of over 150% since the 2018 Awards. The online events provided a platform for hundreds of participants to connect and share their ideas on a range of Green Economy themes in the COVID-19 context including innovative finance, fashion, gastronomy and communication, among others. The Capacity-Building Workshop for Journalists in the framework of “Premios Latinoamerica Verde (PLV)” reached over 175 people and the High Dialogues on Green Economy reached 240.
To expand the message beyond those directly involved in sustainability, the PLV-PAGE alliance organized a two-part Journalist’s Workshop. This workshop was comprised of a discussion with four internationally recognized journalists and a co-creation forum where a group of journalists had the opportunity to build and prepare an environment decalogue. An open call was made to promote an exchange of ideas among projects and build a team with a regional impact. The Co-creation Lab emerged with the objective to connect the PLV community, strengthen projects’ networking abilities and for them to participate in a group activity.
The High-Level Dialogue, the Journalists Workshop and the Co-creation Lab were live streamed on PLV and UNDP LAC’s official accounts. A video produced in collaboration with PLV and UNDP representatives was emailed to greet all the Commercial Platform’s participants. This video has been loaded on PLV’s YouTube channel.
The Green Latin America Awards have considerable potential to grow in line with the regional focus of the new PAGE 2030 Strategy. They provide a platform to showcase inspirational initiatives that are very well aligned to Agenda 2030, and green finance.
